variant.question: An air mass is referred to as stable when

options.text: the vertical motion of rising air tends to become weaker and disappears.
the environmental lapse rate is high, with little vertical motion of air currents.
the temperature in a given air mass decreases rapidly with height.
the pressure in a given area is constant.

variant.question: An air mass is unstable when

options.text: parcels of air may rise or descend spontaneously.
temperature and humidity are not constant.
pressure shows a marked variation over a given horizontal area.

variant.question: An air mass is stable when:

options.text: the vertical motion of parcels of air is suppressed by the atmosphere.
the lapse rate is 1 °C per 100 m.
temperature in a given area drops off very rapidly with height.

variant.question: An air mass is stable when:

options.text: the vertical motion of parcels of air are suppressed by the atmosphere.
the lapse rate is 1 °C per 100 m.
temperature in a given area drops off very rapidly with height.

variant.question: An air mass is stable when

options.text: lifted air returns to its original level.
the lapse rate is 1 °C per 100 m.
temperature in a given area drops off very rapidly with height.

variant.question: An air mass is:

options.text: an extensive body of air within which the temperature and humidity in horizontal planes are practically uniform.
a large body of air within which the temperature and humidity is uniform in horizontal and vertical planes.
a large body of air with temperature and humidity constant in the vertical.
a body of air with a volume of not more than thousand cubic kilometres.

variant.question: An air mass is:

options.text:
An extensive body of air within which the temperature and
humidity in horizontal planes are practically uniform.

A body of air with a volume of not more than thousand
cubic kilometres.

A large body of air within which the temperature and
humidity is uniform in horizontal and vertical planes.

A large body of air with temperature and humidity
constant in the vertical.

variant.question: What are the typical differences with regard to the temperature and humidity between an air mass with its origin in the Azores and an air mass with its origin over northern Russia?

options.text: The air of the Azores is warmer and more humid than the North-Russian air.
The North-Russian air is colder and more humid than the air of the Azores.
The air of the Azores is warmer and dryer than the North-Russian air.
The North-Russian air is warmer and dryer than the air of the Azores.

variant.question: A continental air mass is usually...

options.text: dry, as its moisture content will have reduced while travelling over the land.
moist, as it has picked up moisture during its passage over fields and forests.
cold, as it will have been cooled adiabatically during the night.
warm, as it endures stronger friction over the terrain and is therefore heated up.

variant.question: Characteristic of a cold air mass is:

options.text: altitude, pressure, temperature and the amount of water vapour.
pressure, season, temperature and the amount of water vapour.
